div.p: ἀντὶ πολλῶν ἂν . . . ἑλέσθαι, “you would give a large sum.” ἀντὶ is here “in return for,” not “instead of.” Avoid any translation which would imply that the money and the clear knowledge were two alternatives, either of which the Athenians might receive. The condition in direct speech would run—ἕλοισθε ἄν, εἰ γένοιτο, but εἰσκοπεῖτε is practically an object-clause to ἑλέσθαι.
περὶ ὧν. For περὶ τούτων ἅ.
ὅτε, like most conjunctions of time, can take a causal sense. But (unlike ἐπεί) it is rarely so used.
ἐθέλειν = βουλομένων. The people should be as “willing” to listen as the speakers are “anxious” to be heard.
συμβουλεύειν, sc. ὑμῖν.
εἴ τι κ.τ.λ. Note the careful antithesis of words in εἴ τιτις and πολλὰἐπελθεῖν ἄν.

ἀκούσαντες should be taken as helping out the sense of λάβοιτε, not as conditional. The protasis to ἂν λάβοιτε and ἐπελθεῖν ἂν is εἰ ἐθέλοιτε ἀκούειν understood from the preceding clause. Nor is the meaning of ἀκούειν quite the same in the two cases: if the Athenians will listen, they may chance to hear something to their advantage.
τῆς ὑμετέρας τύχης. The orator, in claiming attention for his impromptu speech, pays a compliment to the ready wit of his countrymen.
τύχης, sc. εἶναι.
ἐπελθεῖν ἄν would in direct speech be ἐπέλθοι ἄν, parallel to ἂν λάβοιτε.
ἁπάντων, neuter.
μόνον οὐχί, L. and S. μόνος, B. II. 5.
ἐκείνων, “over yonder” in Olynthus.
αὐτοῖς, emphatic.
αὐτῶν, i.e. τῶν πραγμάτων.
οὐκ οἶδ’ ὅντινα, euphemistic. Demosthenes keeps direct reproach till later.
τά γ’ ἐμοὶ=τά ἔμοιγε, for euphony.
ἤδη, “at once.”
τὴν ταχίστην. L. and S. ταχύς, C. II. 3.

ὅπως . . . βοηθήσητε. Most editors now read βοηθήσετε with one worthless MS. In favour of the future it may be argued that the more vivid construction, which is also the commonest, is here called for, and that the weak aorist subjunctive is avoided where it resembles the future in form, while the blending of future and subjunctive after ὅπως may be easily paralleled. But there are several well-authenticated instances of the sigmatic aorist after ὅπως in Demosthenes (cf. below, ii. § 2, iii. § 2), which have been recklessly altered.
πρότερον. For historical instances see § 9 (note).
ἥτις . . . ἐρεῖ. The future is regularly used to show purpose.
δέος, predicative.
πανοῦργος, “unscrupulous.”
ἅνθρωπος. Compare the disparaging use of homo in Latin.
δεινός. L. and S. δεινός, III.
πράγμασιν χρῆσθαι, “in making the most of what happens.”
τύχῃ, probably impersonal.
ἀξιόπιστος. Philip the ἄπιστος (ii. § 5) may be trusted only when he threatens.
τρέψηται. The middle is nowhere found in the required sense of “converting to his own advantage.” Any restoration is mere guesswork; perhaps καταστρέψηται is the best suggestion.
τῶν ὅλων πραγμάτων, “of our main interests” (Heslop).
οὐ μὴν ἀλλά, “however,” literally “not but what.”
ἐπιεικῶς with βέλτιστον (φαίνεται). “It may be urged reasonably enough that what is . . . is actually of the greatest advantage to you.”
ἕν’ ὄντα, “alone.” ἕνα is due to πάντων, its opposite. Cf. the use of πλεῖστα εἶς.

καὶ ῥητῶν κἀπορρήτων. Very little more than “secret plans.” The words καὶ ῥηρῶν καὶ merely serve to lead up to ἀπορρήτων, and throw it out into stronger relief. Cf. Virg. Aen. ix. 595, digna atque indigna relatu (=indigna). Hor. Ep. i. 7. 72, dicenda tacenda locutus (=tacenda). Editors, less probably, “his having everything in his sole power to publish or keep secret.”
αὐτόν, emphatic.
ταχύ. ταχέως is more usual in prose, ταχύ in tragedy; τάχα had dropped out of Attic except in τάχ’ ἄν.
πόλλῳ προέχει, literally (his being all-powerful, &c.) “is far superior.” Turn: “in being . . . he has a great advantage over us.”
ἀναστασέως. Understand ὑπέρ, which=περί here as with μέρους, though in a different sense. “To save themselves from utter destruction.”
Ἀμφιπολιτῶν . . . Πυδναίων. The Scholiast says that in each case he lost no time in putting to death those who helped him by their treachery; but we have no trustworthy evidence.
ὅλως, “generally speaking.”
πολιτείαις, “free communities,” a term applied to any form of government administered by πολῖται, and so excluding τυραννίς only: but it is often specially used of democracies.
ὅμορον (ὁμοῦ and ὅρος).
τἄλλα κ.τ.λ. The order is ἐνθυμουμένους πάντα τἄλλα ἃ προσήκει (ἐνθυμεῖσθαι).
ἐθελῆσαι. Note the tense, “rouse your spirit.” So παροξυνθῆναι.
προσέχειν, sc. τὸν νοῦν.
εἴπερ ποτέ, καὶ νῦν=νῦν, εἴπερ ποτέ.
εἰσφέροντας. It must be remembered that the εἰσφορά was not a regular tax, but a highly unpopular war tax to which recourse was rarely had.
λόγος, “reason.”

ἐκπολεμῶσαι, πολεμοῦν τινα=“to make a man hostile,” here hostile to Philip, i.e. to rouse them to fight against him. The old reading ἐκπολεμῆσαι, here and in iii. 7, is impossible, πολεμεῖν being an intrans. verb (“to be at war”), which cannot govern an external acc. Perhaps the confusion arises, in the case of these verbs and of κυκλεῖν, κυκλοῦν, from the fact that the present participles of both verbs have the same form.
καὶ ταῦθ̓, “and that too.”
μέχρι του, “up to a certain point only.”
ταῦτ̓, i.e. τὸ πολεμεῖν.

ἐκ τῶν πρὸς αὑτοὺς ἐγκλημάτων, “as the outcome of personal grievances.” πρὸς is more commonly used, with an acc., of the person against whom the grievance is felt: but as strained relations imply two parties, it may be used with reference to the aggrieved as well. The verb ἐγκαλεῖν is mostly used of legal accusations, the noun ἔγκλημα mostly of general complaints or grounds of complaint.
ὑπὲρ ὧν φοβ. καὶ πεπονθ., “by reason of their present fears and their past experiences.” Philip had in 351 made an attack on Olynthus, and was now (349) threatening the whole Olynthian confederacy.
παθεῖν ταὐτὸν, “commit the same mistake” (Heslop).
ἥκομεν, “had returned,” a frequent sense of the word.

Εὐβοεῦσιν . . . Ἀμφιπολιτῶν. In 358 Athens wrested Euboea from the Thebans, who had held it since the battle of Leuctra (371): it was in 358 or 357 that Philip besieged Amphipolis, and foiled the embassy here mentioned by positively declaring that he would hand the city over to Athens when taken.
παρῆσαν ἐπὶ. For the frequent use of prepositions denoting motion with verbs denoting rest, see L. and S. ἐπὶ, C. 2, εἰς, I. 2.
εἴχετ’ ἄν, not “you would have gained” (ἔσχετ’ ἄν), but “you would have been in possession of.” So παρειχόμεθα is of showing continuous zeal, though “had shown” is all that we can say in English.
πραγμάτων, “trouble.”
Πύδνα κ.τ.λ. To Pydna (357) the Athenians seem to have sent no help at all; to Potidaea (356), Methone (353), and Pagasae (352) they sent too late.
καθ’ ἕκαστα. Object of λέγων, as though it were ἕκαστα alone: not uncommon.
τῷ πρώτῳ, “the first that came.”
αὐτοί, emphatic. Demosthenes constantly insists that a citizen army must be sent out, not a mercenary force.

ῥᾴονι καὶ πολὺ ταπεινοτέρῳ, “more complaisant and far more humble.” The conjunction of the words makes this, the natural rendering, necessary. Dr. Sandys renders “easier to attack and weaker.” But ῥᾴονι can hardly be defended by the parallel
adduced (Hom. Il. 18. 258), and ταπεινός in the sense of “weak” is not used of persons, but of insignificant states compared with a greater power.
νῦν δέ, “but as it is.”
παρὸν . . . ἀεί, to be taken together.
ἡμεῖς, “it is we who have . . . .”
κατεστης. τηλικ. κ.τ.λ. “have raised him to a higher pinnacle than any king of Macedon has ever reached.”
οὐδενὸς ἐλάσσων, “better than any.” Cf. οὐχ ἥκιστα, “above all,” for the Greek love of μείωσις or understatement.
ἄν is almost always divorced from its proper verb by οἶμαι and δοκῶ. Here it is repeated with ἔχειν.
λογιστής. Editors point out that the idea of calculation is followed up in θείη, ἀντίρροπον, and § 11.
καταστὰς . . . ἂν ἔχειν, in direct speech would be εἰ κατασταίη, ἔχοι ἄν.
ὑπηργμένων. L. and S. ὑπάρχω, A. 4.
ἀμελείας . . . θείη. Cf. § 1, τῆς ὑμετέρας τύχης ὑπολαμβάνω.
εὐεργέτημα does not affect the construction of εὐνοίας. It is added to emphasise this as a special instance of general εὔνοια.
The subject to παρόμοιον is something like τὸ τῆς εὐνοίας, i.e. the question of (gratitude for) benefits (in politics).
ὅπερ. The antecedent is τούτῳ understood.
ἂν μὲν γὰρ κ.τ.λ., i.e. ἂν σώσῃ τις ὅς’ ἂν λάβῃ.
συνανήλωσε, momentary aorist.
τὸ μεμνῆσθαι τὴν χάριν. A genitive would be more usual, but cf. Phil. ii. § 30, τοὺς ἀδικοῦντας μεμνῆσθαι. The reading has been suspected without due reason.
τῶν πραγμάτων, “politics.”
οὐδ’ εἰ. Regularly put for καὶ εἰ . . . οὐ.
πρὸς, “in accordance with.”
ἐκβάν, “result.” ἀποβαίνειν is commoner in this sense.
τῶν πρὶν ὑπαρξάντων are the opportunities which they have squandered all along, and for which they feel no gratitude.
προησόμεθα. Here of abandoning men to their fate: supra, § 9, of throwing away opportunities.
εἶτα=κᾆτα, as often. Notice how the absence of connecting particles throughout §§ 12 and 13 adds vigour to the story of Philip's onward course.
τὸ κωλῦον . . . ἔσται. More emphatic and rhetorical than κωλύσει.
βαδίζειν. The word for an advance by land) (πλεῖν, supra, § 8. We might have had μὴ βαδίζειν.
Πύδναν κ.τ.λ. Cf. supra, § 9 (note).

Φεράς. In 352 Philip, after being twice defeated, gained a complete victory over Lycophron, despot of Pherae (who was helped by the Phocians under Onomarchus), and took first that town, then its port, Pagasae.
Μαγνησίαν. Whether the district or a town bearing the same name, is uncertain.
πάνθ̓ sums up the names.
εἰς Θρᾴκην. Still in 352, as we see from iii. § 4. In the interval the Athenians had roused themselves sufficiently to stop his march into Greece at Thermopylæ.
ῥᾴσας . . . ῥᾳθυμεῖν. A pun. “When somewhat recovered he did not relapse into remissness.”
Ὀλυνθίοις ἐπεχείρησεν. Cf. supra, § 7 (note).
Ἰλλυριοὺς καὶ Παίονας. In 351, after a partial conquest, 359-8.
Ἀρύββαν, King of the Molossians.

ἄν τις εἴποι. The authority for ἂν beginning a clause is very slender, but all MSS. give it in § 19, and none here have εἴποι τις
ἄν. In the one passage of Plato where it is found, τί οὖν; precedes, as here and in § 19.
ὡς, “how,” not “that.”
ἀλυσιτελές. Cf. supra, § 9, note on οὐδενὸς ἐλάσσων.
ᾗ χρῆται καὶ συζῇ, “which never leaves him,” “which is his constant attribute and companion.”
ὑφ’ ἧς . . . σχήσει, “which never will suffer him to rest.”
πράττειν, “to aim at.”

ἐλπίς, sc. ἐστί, “we may expect.” Expectation of any kind, not hope only, is the original meaning of the word, cf. the neutral ἔλπομαι. The future or aorist (sometimes present) infinitive may equally be used after verbs of hoping or expecting.
ὅστις ἀγνοεῖ, “that he really does not see,” admitting the possibility more than would ὥστε ἀγνοεῖν.
εἰ τοῦτο γενήσεται, “if this does happen.” The “monitory” form of future protasis.
ἐπὶ τοῖς μεγάλοις τόκοις. ἐπί of the conditions, after δανειζόμενοι. So ἐπὶ πολλῷ, below. The article is unsatisfactory.
τῶν ἀρχαίων, “their original property.”
ἀπέστησαν, gnomic aorist.
ζητοῦντες, sc. ποιεῖν.
ὧν=τούτων ἅ, partitive gen. after πολλά: but the insertion of καὶ χαλεπὰ is awkward.
εἰς ἀνάγκην ἔλθωμεν. With infin., for ἀναγκασθῶμεν.
τὸ μὲν . . . παντὸς εἶναι, τὸ δ’ . . . συμβούλου, “that whereas any one can . . . a counseller should give his opinion.” For the genitives, cf. sapientis est, &c.
ἀποφαίνεσθαι, sc. γνωμήν.
ἐν ὀργῇ ποιεῖσθε. L. and S. ποιέω, A. V.
οὐ μὴν is strongly adversative to μὲν.
σκοποῦντα, sc. ἐμέ, supplied from the succeeding ἡγοῦμαι: or perhaps τινά.
ὑποστείλασθαι. See L. and S. for this favourite metaphor.
δή, “well now,” proceeding to business.
τοῖς πράγμασιν, “the situation,” “the position.”
ἑτέροις, i.e. a second force, different from the reinforcements to be sent to Olynthus.
ὀκνῶ μή. A rare construction. The verb is mostly used of hesitation or shyness. When used of fear, it implies moral fear.
ποιούντων . . . βοηθησάντων. The participles contain the most important part of the condition, the sense being εἰ . . . ποιήσετε καὶ παραστήσεται, and εἰ βοηθήσετε καὶ προσκαθεδεῖται.
παραστήσεται. L. and S. παρίστημι, C. II. 1.
ἀμυνεῖται, sc. τῇ οἰκείᾳ.
προσκ. καὶ προσεδρ. τοῖς πραγ., “vigorously blockade and besiege the position” (Dr. Sandys).
ουδενί. Vague and strange for οὐδέσι (v.l.), or οὐδεμίᾳ πόλει.

[στρατιωτικά], if retained, spoils the whole section, in which Demosthenes is walking with great caution over thin ice, in referring to the uses of the Theoric Fund (for which see note on iii. § 11). With studied vagueness he says, “Money you have, but you take (i.e. spend) it according to your own tastes.” With στρατιωτικά retained, these last words become a direct reproof, after which τί οὖν;ἔγωγε is absurd. And Demosthenes would scarcely be so fatuous as to say, “Far be it from me to propose that the military fund should be a military fund.”
ἄν τις εἴποι. Cf. supra, § 14 (note).

ταῦτ’ εἶναι στρατιωτικά. These words do not clash with μὰ Δί̓ οὐκ ἔγωγε, because ἡγοῦμαι is strongly opposed to γράφεις. In effect: “I think it the right course, I admit, but you will insist on spending the money your own way: then why should I make a useless proposal?”

μίαν σύνταξιν κ.τ.λ., literally “that there should be one and the same regulation for taking money and doing one's duty,” i.e. that only those who perform military service should get money from the state.
οὕτω πως, “just anyhow.” See L. and S. οὕτως, IV.
ἑορτάς. The first definite reference to τὸ θεωρικόν.

δή marks a real proposal. But it is only made in order to force the people to the course which Demosthenes dare not himself propose. He passes on hastily from the hated εἰσφορά to the general conclusion δεῖ δὲ χρημάτων.
δεῖ . . . δεόντων. Play on words.
εὐτρεπῶς, “ship-shape.”
ὡς ἂν κάλλιστα, sc. ἔχοι.
αὐτόν. Sometimes wrongly taken as standing for πόλεμον.

ὡς ἐπιών. Explained as=ἐξ ἐπιδρομῆς, “at the first onset.” This is probably right, but, as Dr. Sandys points out, this use of ὡς is elsewhere confined to adverbs and adverbial phrases (ὡς ἀληθῶς, ὡς ἐπὶ τὸ πολύ, &c.).
ἅπαντα . . . ἀναιρήσεσθαι, “carry everything with him,” the metaphor in Greek being the same.
τὰ τῶν Θετταλῶν, “the attitude of the Thessalians”: taken up by ταῦτα, where οὗτοι would be more natural.
κομιδῇ, sc. ἄπιστα, “uncommonly treacherous.” The origin of this colloquial adverb is as uncertain as that of the very similar oppido in Latin.
ὥσπερ ἦν merely repeats the μὲν clause.
δώσοιεν. The future optative is only used after historic tenses of verbs of saying, thinking, or planning, to represent a fut. indic. in direct speech: but very commonly the indic. is kept.
καρποῦσθαι, explanatory infinitive.
δέοι. By a very rare use the construction of ὡς is continued where we should expect δεῖν.
τὰ κοινὰ . . . διοικεῖν, “to provide for state expenses.”
τοῖς ξένοις. Dative after a substantive. Cf. Latin obtemperatio legibus, &c.
ἀλλὰ μήν, literally “but verily,” introduces a new point, like καὶ μήν. γε strengthens the asseveration, not τὸν Παίονα.
ἂν εἶναι for ἂν εἶεν of direct speech.
τινός, “a master.” Not “any master.”
ἅνθρωπος. Cf. supra, § 3 (note).
οὐδέν, adverbial.
τὸ γὰρ εὖ κ.τ.λ. Philip is ὑβριστής, because, according to the old Greek proverb, τίκτει κόρος ὕβριν. Translate “Undeserved success puts the senseless on the road to folly.”
ἀφορμή, literally a starting-point.
τὴν ἀκαιρίαν . . καιρὸν . . νομ., “regarding his time of need as your time for action.”
ἐφ’ ἃ δεῖ, “for the necessary purposes.”
πρὸς τῇ χώρᾳ, sc. τῇ ἡμετέρᾳ.

πῶς οἴεσθε does not affect the construction of λογιζ. ἂν ἐλθεῖν αὐτόν, being merely a colloquial way of turning ἑτοίμως into a superlative. Cf. Av. Ach. 24 ὠστιοῦνται πῶς δοκεῖς; / ἐλθόντες ἀλλήλοισι περὶ πρώτου ξύλου.

εἰ μηδ̓ . . . οὐ τολμήσετε. αἰσχύνομαι, like θανμάζω, ἀγανακτῶ, &c., may be followed by εἰ οὐ or εἰ μή. Euphony and habit produce εἰ μὴ here (as in ii. § 25), and we expect a positive verb to follow, εἰ μηδ’ ἃ being for εἰ καὶ ἃ . . . μὴ (τολμήσετε). But when that part of μηδέ which means “even” has done its duty, Demosthenes disregards the μή, and gives a more vivid picture with οὐ τολμήσετε.
πάθοιτε = ποιῆσαι, “to treat him as he would treat you.”
τὴν ὑπάρχουσαν implies only length of tenure: τὴν οἰκείαν appeals to sentiment. Attica, of course, is referred to.
Θηβαῖοι, like ἀλλὰ Φωκεῖς and ἀλλ’ ὧ τᾶν, is the answer of an imaginary objector. The Thebans were united with Philip against the Phocians in the Sacred War.

μὴ λίαν πικρὸν ἦ, “perhaps it may be too hard a saying, but . . .” This is said to be the only instance in the orators of μή introducing an independent cautious assertion. Plato is very fond of this construction, in which the idea of actual fear is never present, nor is a verb of fearing understood before μή. “We have here the original deprecatory force of ‘μή, let it not.’ In a writer like Plato this μή has become simply a suggestion put politely, and with a delicate irony” (Thompson, Attic Syntax).
τῶν ἀτοπωτάτων, neuter.
ἂν εἴη, εἰ μὴ πράξει. The fut. indic. is allowed, because optat. with ἂν is here only a softened form of the future; and πράξει is more telling, as it almost prophesies action on the part of Philip.
ἐκλαλεῖ, “blurts out,” not “blabs.”
ἡλίκ’ ἐστὶν τὰ διάφορα=ὅσον διαφέρει. The infin. following is very rare.
αὐτούς, either referring to personal service, or (more probably) to the absence of an enemy.
ἔξω, sc. τῆς πόλεως, in Attica.
ἀνάγκη, sc. ἐστὶ λαμβάνειν.
λέγω, “I mean,” introducing the conditional clause μηδενὸς ὄντος.
ἡ ὕβρις, i.e. the outrages inflicted by the enemy. Unlike ὑβριστής, supra, § 23.
τῶν πραγμάτων, “such a state of affairs.”
οὐδεμιᾶς ἐλάττων. Cf. supra, § 9 (note).
ἀπωθεῖν does not imply that the war is now in Attica, but that it must be thrust into Macedonia before it comes (ἥξει above).
ὧν, attraction of relative.
καλῶς ποιοῦντες. Here a formula of content rather than of thanks. “Which they happily possess” (Heslop).
ε<>ν ἡλικίᾳ, sc. στρατεύεσθαι.
φοβεροί. A strong word, suggesting a terrifying aspect. Translate “dread” or “grim,” not “formidable” or “redoubtable.”
ἀκεραίου (ἀ. κεράννυμι) is proleptic, as the position of the article shows. “To keep it inviolate” (Heslop).

τῶν πεπολιτευμένων αὐτοῖς. The dative of the agent is rarely used except as neuter plural after perfect passives (usually the participle). The dative after πράττω is far the most common instance (cf. below, τῶν πεπραγμένων αὐτοῖς).
εὔθυναι, metaphorical.
πράγματα, “circumstances”; πεπραγμένων, “conduct.”
χρηστὰ δ’ εἴη. The more important speeches of Demosthenes usually end with words of good omen, sometimes couched, as here, in the form of a prayer.
ἐπὶ πολλῶν. L. and S. ἐπὶ, A. III. 3.
γιγνομένην. Notice the tense. “To see . . . being openly vouchsafed.”
τῇ πόλει depends both on εὔνοιαν and φαν. γιγν.

τὸ γὰρ κ.τ.λ. The long sentence introduced by τὸ γεγενῆσθαι and extending to ἀνάστασιν is the subject of ἔοικεν. Turn: “for it seems really a . . . blessing that men have come forward to fight . . . who are.”
τοὺς πολεμήσοντας=τινὰς οἳ πολεμήσουσι. Here the future denotes willingness rather than purpose.
ὅμορον, sc. Φιλίππῳ.
τινά, “considerable.”
πατρίδος . . . ἀνάστασιν, “their country's deathblow.” More forcible than πατοίδα ἀναστησούσας.
αὐτούς, emphatic: self-help is needed, as well as divine help
ὅπως μὴ . . . δόξωμεν. Cf. i. § 2 (note).
χείρους . . . τῶν ὑπαρχ. “Less kind to ourselves (Heslop) than circumstances have been to us,” literally than what we have already.
τῶν αἰσχρῶν, neuter. Cf. i. § 26, τῶν ἀτοπωτάτων μεντἂν εἴη.
πόλεων. Inversely attracted from acc. by the succeeding relative ὧν.

ἔχειν φιλοτιμίαν, “does honour to his enterprise.” φιλοτιμία is properly an emulous seeking after distinction, but here the second factor in the word is used twice, as though it were τιμὴν ὑπὲρ φιλοτιμίας. It is never merely “honour,” as taken by editors here and elsewhere, but honour for showing public spirit or the like.

οὐχὶ καλῶς πεπρᾶχθαι. Some such word as αἰσχύνην was expected to finish the sentence after ἡμῖν δ̓, but Demosthenes changes it to a vaguer phrase which does not follow ἔχειν at all, but δοκεῖ. “While to us—it is a record of failure.”
ὑπὲρ τὴν ἀξίαν, “beyond what he deserves.” Cf. i. § 23.
κεχρῆσθε τοῖς πράγμασι. Cf. i. § 3.
αἰσχύνην ὠφλήκατε. Defines οὐχὶ καλῶς πεπρᾶχθαι above.
σκοποῖτο. Rarer than σκέψαιτο.
ἐνθένδε, not merely “from Athens” but “from this spot,” i.e. the assembly or platform, as shown by τοῖς . . . πεπολιτευμένοις.
ὧν follows both χάριν and δίκην, thanks for, vengeance for.
τοῖς . . . πεπολιτευμένοις, middle.
λέγειν, sc. ταῦτα, from ὧν.
ἃ δέ. The relative is carried on with the next two clauses.
ἔνι, sc. λέγειν.
ἀκηκοέναι. The tense is important.
βουλομένοις, conditional.
δοκιμάζειν, sc. αὐτά. Always used of a close scrutiny: technically of examining a magistrate before he was admitted to office, or a youth before he was classed among men.
ἐλέγχειν, sc. αὐτὸν ἐπίορκον κἄπιστον ὄντα.
τοῦ τ’ . . . καὶ τοὺς. . . Some MSS., but not the best, give τοῦ again after καί. Its omission is certainly curious, but not unparalleled.
ὑπερεκπεπληγμένους. For the acc., cf. Soph. El. 1045, καὶ μὴν ποιήσω γ’ , οὐδὲν ἐκπλαγεῖσά σε.

διεξελήλυθεν . . . “has run through all the arts of deception by which he rose to greatness” (Heslop). Others, with little probability (though the Greek will bear the rendering), take διεξ. intransitive, with πάντα as subject.
παρακρουόμενος. The metaphor is obscure: see L. and S. for two explanations of Byzantine lexicographers: neither is convincing.
μέγας, proleptic.
τὰ πράγματ’ αὐτοῦ, “his career” (Heslop).
σφόδρα, with the adjectives.

τὴν . . . εὐήθειαν . . . προσαγαγόμενον, “that he won over our simple hearts by declaring . . .” The participle agrees with τὸν Φίλιππον understood from above. εὐήθειαν, which is thrown prominently forward, is separated from its governing verb first by a temporal sentence and then by the instrumental τῷ . . . φάσκειν . . . καὶ . . . (τῷ) κατασκευάσαι.
Ὀλυνθίους, i.e. Hierax and Stratocles in 358-7. See i. § 8.
ἀπήλαυνον, imperfect of attempt, though not necessarily unsuccessful. So Heslop, “set themselves to . . .”
ἐνθένδε, as supra, § 4 (note).
θρυλούμενον, imperfect participle, helped out by ποτέ.
ἀπόρρητον. The secret agreement was that Philip should hand over Amphipolis to Athens, and receive Pydna in exchange.
κατασκευάσαι. For the omission of τῷ cf. supra, § 5 (note on τοῦ). The word is used of “trumping up” a fraudulent pretext.
φιλίαν and Θετταλοὺς are governed by προσαγ. carried on.

καὶ τοὺς μὲν . . . Where any antithesis may be made, the Greeks prefer co-ordinate sentences with μὲν and δὲ, where we should say “and by wronging his former allies (the Potidæans) in handing them over to the Olynthians.” Here the antithesis between verbs and datives is merely verbal, but it is accentuated by chiasmus.
Μαγνησίαν παραδώσειν. No such promise is recorded elsewhere.
ἀεὶ with ἑκάστων, “of each in turn.” A common use of ἀεὶ, especially with participles. Cf. infra, § 30 (note).
προσλαμβάνων, literally “taking to himself,” i.e. “turning to his own use.”
οὕτως takes up ἐξαπατῶν and προσλαμβάνων. Omit in translation.
διὰ τούτων and διὰ τῶν αὐτῶν τούτων are neuters. It was by means of cheating that Philip raised himself; he will be dragged down now that (ἐπειδὴ) he has been proved a cheat.
ὀφείλει, not “he ought to,” but “he owes to,” i.e. in retribution will be dragged down.
καιροῦ . . . πρὸς τοῦτο=πρὸς τοῦτον τὸν καιρόν.
πρὸς . . . πάρεστι. Cf. i. § 8 (note).
ἢ. The first ἢ is “or else” (cf. Latin aut), the others “or.”
πιστεύσουσι, sc. αὐτῷ.

παρὰ τὴν αὑτῶν ἀξίαν, “unworthily” rather than “undeservedly.” Either rendering might do for παρὰ τὴν ἀξίαν, i. § 23, and ὑπὲρ τὴν ἀξίαν, ii. § 3; but here the added genitive takes the words out of the region of a mere phrase, and calls attention to the inherent “worth” of the Thessalians as Greeks.

καθέξειν . . . τὰ πράγματα, “will control events.” I can see no reason, and find no warrant, for the rendering “will maintain his power” (Dr. Sandys, Heslop). Even in poetry κατέχειν never has this sense.
ὅταν . . . συστῇ. Cf. i. 12 (note).
ὑπ’ εὐνοίας . . . συστῇ. As the passive of συνέχειν, συστῆναι is followed by a preposition of the agent. So ἀποθανεῖν (passive of ἀποκτείνειν), &c.
φέρειν. συμφέρειν, which might have been expected after συμπονεῖν, is only poetical in the sense required, and would also have involved a pun.
πρόφασις, “cause.” Usually=“plea” or “pretext.”
ἀνεχαίτισεν. Gnomic aorist. In using this strong metaphor Demosthenes recalls to the memory of his audience two passages from Euripides (Hipp. 1232, Bacch. 1072) well known to them.
καὶ διέλυσεν. Either an added metaphor opposed to συστῇ, or, more probably, the metaphor is a “buried” one—the more common verb (“destroys”) balancing and toning down the bold ἀνεχαίτισεν.
εἰς with ἅπαξ only, forming one word.
ἤνθης’ ἐπὶ ταῖς ἐλπίσιν, “puts forth the blossoms of hope,” literally blossoms on hopes. The whole metaphor has a parallel in Shakespeare, Henry VIII., Act iii. Sc. 2:—
“This is the state of man: to-day he puts forth The tender leaves of hope, to-morrow blossoms, And bears his blushing honours thick upon him: The third day comes a frost, a killing frost.”
ἂν τύχῃ. Cf. i. § 3 (note).
φωρᾶται curiously disturbs the metaphor. Metaphor and application are joined as in ἀνεχ. κ. διελυς. above, but in inverse order.

περὶ αὑτὰ καταρρεῖ. Like fading flowers round the stem of the
plant (Heslop), καταρρεῖν being the regular word for the falling of leaves or petals.

ἀρχὰς . . . ὑποθέσεις. The words are carefully chosen with a view to the simile, each being used both of material “foundations” and of moral or intellectual “principles.” Cf. ii. 2, τὴν ἀρχὴν ὀρθῶς ὑποθέσθαι.
οὐκ ἔνι, “is not to be found.”
δή. Cf. i. § 17 (note).
ὅπως for ὡς, with the superlatives.
λέγει, “proposes.”
ταῦτα, i.e. our preparations.
Παγασὰς ἀπαιτεῖν. Cf. i. § 22. The perfect tense used in both cases shows that the claim was a recent one, and that the two speeches were delivered about the same time.
λόγους ποιεῖσθαι, “to remonstrate” (Heslop).
δεικνύειν (more commonly δεικνύναι), to “point to,” not, of course, to “display.”
ὄντων ἐπὶ τοῖς πράγμασιν, “devoting yourselves to action.”
ἃν ἀπῇ. A general supposition in present time: the apodosis of such conditions is always in present (or gnomic aorist) indicative.
τὰ πράγματα. A better antithesis would be τὰ ἔργα (given by one good MS.).
ἑτοιμότατα. We should expect the comparative.
αὐτῷ, i.e. speechifying, in which the Athenians were proficient beyond all others.
δοκοῦμεν, “are reputed.”
μετάστασιν, “reformation,” μεταβολὴν, “change,” the former denoting a more fundamental and lasting alteration.
εἴπερ . . . προσέξει, “if you expect any one to attend to you.” For εἰ μέλλει προσέχειν, but shows more impatience.
ἐθελήσητε. Cf. i. § 6 (note).
καὶ δή=ἤδη. With an infinitive it is curious and very graphic. v.l. καὶ δεῖ.
τὰ συμμαχικά. Practically equal to οἱ σύμμαχοι.
ἐν προσθήκῃ, “as a complement.” For the use of ἐν cf. ἐν παρέργῳ, “as a secondary consideration.” Cf. iii. § 31 (note).
μερίς, literally share, i.e. “addition.”
οἷον ὑπῆρξε . . . “For example, it was of assistance to you.” The verb should be taken as absolute, parallel to ἐφάνη τι and ἐβοήθησεν. Others understand μερὶς οὐ μικρά.

ἐπὶ Τιμοθέου. In 364 B.C. the Athenian commander Timotheus led a force against the Olynthian league, and with the help of Perdiceas III., elder brother and predecessor of Philip, took Torone and Potidaea.
ἐφάνη τι, “proved considerable.”
τοῦτο, i.e. the Macedonians.
συναμφότερον. Two constructions are blended:—
1. Ὀλυνθίοις . . . τοῦτο προσγενόμενον.
2. τοῦτο (of Macedonians and Olynthians combined) συναμφότερον.
νυνί, “lately,” rarely used of past time without δή.
ἐπὶ τὴν τυραννικὴν οἰκίαν. See i. § 13, note on Φεράς.

κἂν. The ἂν in this word has no regular construction, though no doubt the preceding ἂν facilitates its use. From the fact that καὶ ἂν often began a conditional sentence, κἂν εἰ came to be used for καὶ εἰ, and then κἂν alone for καὶ “even.” Cf. Soph. El. 1482, ἀλλά μοι πάρες / κἂν σμικρὸν εἰπεῖν.
πάντ’ ὠφελεῖ, “it is altogether of service,” πάντα being acc. plur. adverbial.
κακῶν, “weak points.”
τούτοις, instrumental, οἷς, causal dative.
τοῦτ’ ἐζήλωκεν, “has made this his passion” (Sandys). τοῦτο= τὸ δόξης ἐπιθυμεῖν.
προῄρηται. Always of deliberately choosing a definite course: whereas just below the simple αἱρει<>σθαι, followed by ἀντί, is of preferring one course to another.
πράττων κ.τ.λ., i.e. πράττειν τε καὶ κινδυνεύειν καὶ παθεῖν . . . “To run a career of action and peril, and therein to suffer . . .”
ἂν συμβῇ τι=ὅ τι ἂν συμβῇ, object of παθεῖν.
τὴν . . . δόξαν, a long stretch.
φιλοτιμίας, “glory.” Cf. ii. § 3 (note).
κοπτόμενοι, “shattered.” A very strong word.
ταῖς ἄνω κάτω, “hither and thither.” ἄνω κάτω is more common in the sense of “upside down.”
τοῖς ἔργοις, “agriculture.” A special use of the word which was never quite lost in Greek. Cf. the title of Hesiod's agricultural poem, Ἔργα καὶ Ἡμέραι.
ποιήσωσιν, “produce”—the earliest meaning of the verb, the sense “to do” being a later extension. Cf. ποιητής.
οὕτως ὅπως ἂν δυν., “as best they can,” i.e. under these difficulties.
διαθέσθαι, “to dispose of” by sale, literally to arrange for their advantage.
Φιλίππῳ. For the more usual πρὸς Φίλιππον.
οἱ δὲ δή. The δή is probably ironical.
οὐδ. οἵου τε ψευδ. So we say of a man that “he couldn't tell a lie if he wanted to.”
οὐδένων . . . βελτίους. Cf. i. § 9 (note).

οἷος ἔμπειρος. The verb ἐστὶν may be easily understood after οἷος, and of course this is grammatically the origin of such an expression. But, as part of a phrase, οἶος is depreciatory and almost adverbial, “to any extent skilled.” E.g. in Av. Vesp. 970, ὁ δ’ ἕτερος οἷός ἐστιν οἰκουρὸς μόνον, where the position of ἐστιν makes anything but a colloquial explanation of οἷος impossible.
φιλοτιμίᾳ, “through personal ambition.”
ἔφη. The subject is to be supplied from the τινός of § 17, fin.
τοῖς ἄλλοις, i.e. his other failings.
τὴν φιλοτ. ἀνυπ. The adjective may quite naturally be taken as agreeing with τὴν φιλ. (τοῦ Φιλίππου). Others take it with τὸν Φίλιππον understood, τὴν φιλ. being acc. of respect.
ἄλλως. Such an idiomatic use of ἄλλος is scarcely to be translated. It means properly “to take another virtue, besides σωφροσύνη.”
λοιπούς, predicate.

οἵους . . . ὀρχεῖσθαι, “the sort of people to . . .” Contrast supra, § 17, οἵου τε ψεύδεσθαι. The ultimate reason for the distinction made in sense by the addition of τε is obscure. Demosthenes probably alludes to κορδακισμοὺς above.
ὀκνῶ has here its proper meaning. See i. § 17 (note).
θαυματοποιῶν, “mountebanks.”
τὸν δημόσιον. This term is so general for a public slave, or servant, that we can only guess at the occupation of Callias. He may have been a clerk like Æschines.
μίμους, verbal, not substantival. So ποιητάς (cf. supra, § 16, note on ποιήσωσι).
εἵνεκα τοῦ γελασθῆναι, literally for the sake of their (τοὺς συνόντας) being laughed at, i.e. “to raise a laugh at their expense.”

τούτους ἀγαπᾷ. Rarely used as a transitive verb of “feeling affection for,” except in the Homeric ἀγαπάζω. Plato and the classical writers generally use it in the sense of being content, with dative, conjunction, or participle.

κακοδαιμονίας. An evil δαίμων or genius might bring a man (1) utter wretchedness, or (2) madness, infatuation, as here. The literal meaning is more constant in this word than in its opposite εὐδαιμονία. The words γν. καὶ κακ. are not a hendiadys; καὶ does not couple, but explains, as often, the vaguer by the more definite word, literally “the state of his mind, I mean his infatuation.”
τούτοις, i.e. τοῖς δείγμασι.
τὸ κατορθοῦν. Used as an intrans. verb by prose writers only: as trans. it is, like ἀνορθοῦν, a favourite of the tragedians.
πταίσει, sc. ὁ Φίλιππος.
αὐτοῦ depends on ταῦτ̓.

δείξειν. Understand αὐτὸ (often expressed) as subject, literally “that the event will show” (i.e. “what it will show,” not “what I say”). Besides δείξει and αὐτὸ δείξει, we have αὐτὸ δηλώσει (Dem.) and αὐτὸ σημανεῖ (Eur.).
θέλωσι . . . βούλησθε. Cf. i. § 1 (note).

ἕως, MSS. τέως. On such a point the authority of MSS. is almost valueless. In the time of Demosthenes τέως had its own duties as demonstrative, and it is hard to believe that it could be relative as well. Later, it ousted ἔως as relative, and copyists persistently wrote the form familiar to their own age.
οὐδὲν ἐπαισθάνεται, “does not notice that anything is wrong,” the sense of οὐδὲν being made clear in the following clause.
κινεῖται, “is disturbed.”
κἂν ῥῆγμα, κἂν στρέμμα, sc. ᾖ, not σαθρὸν ᾖ.
τῶν ὑπαρχόντων, “of the system.”
πόλεμος συμπλακῇ. More forcible than πολεμῷ συμπλακῶσιν, as showing that the war has the grip of them and they are likely to be thrown.
ἐποίησεν. For the tense, cf. supra, § 9, ἀνεχαίτισεν.
ταύτῃ, “in this respect.”
μὲν introduces a polite concession to this view; οὐ μὴν ἀλλὰ opposes it.
μεγάλη . . . ῥοπή, literally “is a great preponderance,” i.e. “makes a great difference.” More commonly ῥοπὴν ἔχειν.
μᾶλλον δὲ τὸ ὅλον, “or rather, all the difference.” Take τὸ ὄλον adverbially, ῥοπή ἐστι being equivalent to ῥέπει.
αὐτῶν, emphatic.
κατὰ μικρόν is found meaning (1) “little by little,” (2) “to a slight extent,” as here.
πλείους ἀφορμὰς εἰς, “more to depend upon for,” literally startingpoint, then “capital,” which is the metaphor here. Cf. i. § 23.
οἶμαι, “to be sure.”
αὐτὸν, sc. τινὰ, “a man himself.”

μή τί γε, “much less.” Cf. Latin ncdum (sometimes nc). In both cases there is an ellipse of a subjunctive, here ἐπιτάττῃς. The full construction would be, “I say not even, lest you should think you can order.”
ἐφ’ ἅπασι, “on all occasions.”
μήτε καιρὸν μήθ’ ὥραν παραλ. A slight zeugma.
ἐκεῖνο. The object thrown forward, referring to what follows. In English we can only say “this,” not “that”; but cf. Latin illud (commoner than hoc).

εἰ Λακ. μὲν . . . νυνὶ δὲ. . . . A good example of the Greek use of co-ordinate clauses, where we should make the four main verbs in the μέν clauses subordinate. They say, “I wonder that you did indeed resist,” &c. (as we know that you did), “but that now . . .” where surprise is not expressed at the resistance, but at the subsequent slackness in face of previous resistance. In English, “That, whereas you resisted,” &c. “you now. . . .”

Λακεδ . . . ἀντήρατε. This refers to the war taken up in 378 B.C. by Athens and Thebes. The independent rights of Greek cities, which had been secured in 387, had been constantly violated by Sparta, notably when she seized the Acropolis of Thebes in 383.
δικαίων, “rights.”
τύχωσι, more graphic than τύχοιεν.
προεκινδυνεύετε, sc. τῶν ἄλλων.
καθ̓ ἕν̓ αὐτῶν. καθ̓ ἕνα forms a substantive here=ἕκαστον. So καθ’ ἕκαστα, i. § 9 (note).
πόσον πολεμεῖτε χρόνον. So πάλαι, πολὺν χρόνον, and Latin iamdudum, iampridem take present, not past.
τί ποιούντων, i.e. τί ἐποιεῖτε ἐν ᾧ ὁ χρόνος. . . So μελλόντων and the other participles below. Cf. i. § 18 (note).
αὐτῶν = ἑτέρους τινάς.
κρινόντων, sc. τοὺς στρατηγούς.
πάλιν ἐλπιζόντων. In connection with κριν. as the Schol. shows. The accused generals would be prodigal of promises.
ἀγνωμόνως ἔχετε. ἀγνώμων is (1) unreasoning, as here; (2) unfeeling.
ὥστε . . . ἐλπίζετε. Cf. note on ὅστις ἀγνοεῖ, i. § 15, “that you really expect.”
ἔχον ἐστὶ φύσιν=ἔχει φύσιν. φύσις forms no adjective of the required sense, but ἔχον ἐστὶ φύσιν parallels εὔλογον more closely than would ἔχει φύσιν.
ἔχοντας φυλάττειν, for φυλ. ἅ ἄν τις ἔχῃ.
πάντα, object of κτήσασθαι, and perhaps, but not necessarily, of φυλάττειν as well.

τὰ καθ’ ὑμᾶς ἐλλείμματα, “your own shortcomings.” And at the same time (says Demosthenes) your new vigour will leave the generals no excuses: you will be able, when your objects are gained, to judge them on their merits, since you are so fond of judging.
πικρῶς, “severely.” Very rare in a good sense.
εἰ δεῖ τι, “if I must state a fact or two about the generals as well” (on whose faults you are always insisting, but who seem to me outside the question).
ἐνταῦθα μέν, “whereas in this war” (your war with Philip).

κἂν ληφθῇ, sc. τἆθλα, for Ἀμφίπολις is almost certainly a gloss, as this speech is in no way concerned with the recovery of Amphipolis, and the position of καί in κἂν is very awkward. Moreover, λήμματα below shows clearly that ληφθῇ is used in a general sense of prizes of war. Ἀμφίπολις was probably inserted by a copyist or commentator who was not equal to giving more than the most literal meaning to ληφθῇ.

ὑμεῖς, emphatic, opposed to ἴδιοι. In the war with Philip the generals and soldiers run all the risks, and you would get all the prizes of success: in their self-sought wars, they run fewer risks and get considerable profit.
μισθὸς δ’ οὐκ ἔστιν, “and reward they have none,” i.e. to compensate for the risks. It need not mean that they could not get their pay.
δόντες λόγον. διδόναι λόγον is (1) to render an account, (2) to grant a hearing, as here and infra, § 31.
τὰς ἀνάγκας, “their hard case.”

περίεστι, “the result is,” literally “it remains over.” The preposition in this verb (as in περιγίγνομαι, &c.) has its less usual force (like the Epic περί with gen.) of “beyond,” “exceeding.” Thus περιεῖναι is (1) to surpass, with gen., (2) to remain over, whether as a survival or as a consequence.
ὑμῖν. We should expect μέν to follow, to parallel τὰ κοινὰ δ̓.
ἐρίζειν. A poetical (and Platonic) word.

κατὰ συμμορίας. Demosthenes here metaphorically applies the rules for tax-collecting to party politics. When a certain εἰσφορά was needed in 377 B.C., it was arranged that henceforth it should be collected from four classes, graduated in wealth, with a ἡγεμών (“head”) and an ἐπιμελητής (“superintendent”) attached to each. The highest class numbered the 300 most wealthy citizens, the second more (less wealthy), the third more still, and the fourth most of all. [L. and S. are wrong in speaking of the 1200 most wealthy citizens: this applies only to the extension of συμμορίαι to the trierarchy, which took place in 357 B.C.—an arrangement with which, though prior to this speech, we are not concerned here.] Applying this system to the state of the two political parties, Demosthenes says that each party has a ῥήτωρ (corresponding to the ἡγεμών) and a στρατηγός (corr. to the ἐπιμελητής). The ῥήτωρ defends the στρατηγός (e.g. Chares) in the assembly. And each side has its noisy partisans (corresponding, very inaccurately, it must be confessed, to the 300 wealthiest citizens). Translate: “For in former times you were divided into partnerships for paying the war-tax: now you are divided into partnerships for playing the politician.”
ἑκατέρων refers back to τοῖς μὲν . . . τοῖς δὲ . . . above.
ὡς. L. and S. C. iii.
ταῦτ’ ἐπανέντας, literally “relaxing this,” i.e. “abandoning this policy.”

ὑμῶν αὐτῶν . . . γενομένους. γίγνεσθαι with gen. is (1) “to become one of,” e.g. Ar. Nub. 107, τούτων γενοῦ μοι, “please join them,” (2) with gen. of reflexive pronoun, “to become one's own master,” as here.
κοινόν, “free to all.”

ὥσπερ ἐκ τυραννίδος ὑμῶν, literally “as though from the position of a tyranny over you,” i.e. “as though they exercised lordship over you.” The gen. construction which follows the verb τυραννεύειν is here extended to the noun.
τοῖς δὲ ψηφ. μόνον. The first class has all the power, the second all the duties, the third has only votes, and these it uses against the generals, trierarchs, &c., of the second class (κατὰ τούτων).
ἀεί, with ἠδικημένον, in the idiomatic sense. “That class which at the particular time has been unjustly treated.” Cf. § 7.
εἶτα=κᾆτα. Cf. i. § 12.
ἔξεσται, ironical.
λέγω, “I bid you.”
δή. Cf. i. § 17 (note).
κεφάλαιον, literally “as a summing-up.”
ὁ δεῖνα. In Demosthenes we find:— Sing. Plur. N. ὁ δεῖνα. οἱ δεῖνες. Too close. A. τὸν δεῖνα. — G. τοῦ δεῖνος. τῶν δείνων. D. τῷ δεῖνι. —
The derivation of the word is very obscure.
οὐχὶ ταὐτὰ . . . γιγνώσκειν, “to take a totally different view.” For the μείωσις, cf. i. § 9 (note).
προήκοντα. Represents the same tense as προελήλυθεν, § 3.

ὥστε . . . δέον=ὥστε δεῖ. But as the whole sentence is subordinate to ὁρῶ, which is followed by a participle, δεῖ follows suit. Cf. Goodw. M.T. 607 (a). Others, with less probability, understand ἐστί (δέον ἐστὶ=δεῖ).
κακῶς, with πεισόμεθα.
οὐδὲν ἄλλο . . . ἤ. Originally some such word as ποιεῖν would be expressed to govern οὐδὲν ἄλλο. But it has become almost an adverbial phrase, “merely.”
τὴν ὑπόθεσιν, “the subject,” literally “groundwork.” Cf. the derivation of the word “subject.”
οὐχὶ τὴν οὖσαν=ψευδῆ.
ἁμαρτάνειν. Absolute, with παριστ. “to be at fault in. . . . ”
γέγονεν . . . ταῦτ’ ἀμφότερα, “both these chances have been offered to us.”
τοῦτο. Object of προλαβεῖν, explained by ὅπωσσώσομεν.
βεβαίως ὑπάρξῃ, “has been effectively secured.”
τὴν πρώτην. L. and S. πρότερος, B. iii. 1. Cf. infra, § 21, τὴν ἄλλως.
σώσωμεν. Cf. i. § 2 (note).
περὶ τοῦ τίνα τιμ. τις, literally “as to the (question) whom one shall punish.” The article makes the direct question τίνα τιμ. τις; into a substantive. The alliteration is perhaps intentional.
ὃν τρόπον=τίνα τρόπον. The relative is sometimes used for the interrogative, though a distinction may be marked in most cases.
τὴν ἀρχὴν . . . ὑποθέσθαι, “to lay the foundation.” Cf. ii. § 10, τὰς ἀρχὰς καὶ τας ὑποθέσεις. 1, τὴν ὑπόθεσιν (note).
ὀρθῶς, “aright.” Appropriate to the building metaphor. Cf. ὀρθοῦν (poetical) and ἀνορθοῦν (prose), specially used of the restoration of temples, forts, or houses.
εἴπερ ποτέ. A curious blending of (1) ὁ παρὼν καιρός, εἴπερ τις, δεῖται, (2) νῦν, εἴπερ ποτε, δεῖ.
ἀκούων, “by hearsay.”
τῶν πραγμάτων, “our interests.”
ἤ. Depends on τὰ πλείω. Where the article is used with the comparative (as here), we generally find μᾶλλον ἤ.
διὰ τοῦτο, “with this motive.” διά, with accusative, usually means “because of.”
πρὸς χάριν, “to give pleasure.” So we have πρὸς ἡδονὴν λέγειν (Thuc. ii. 65).
δημηγορεῖν. Cf. δημαγωγεῖν.
εἰς πᾶν . . . μοχθηρίας, “to the utmost limit of wret<*>hedness.”
μίκρά=ὀλίγα.
μέμνησθε . . . ὅτε. The antecedent to ὅτε is omitted (τοῦτον τὸν χρόνον). So, in English, “You remember when.”
ἀπηγγέλθη . . . πολιορκῶν. An extension of the use of the participle after verbs of hearing and knowing (ἀκούω, οἶδα, &c.). Cf. i. § 9.

τρίτον . . . ἔτος τουτί. In 352, November to December (μαιμακτηριών). The expedition is mentioned in i. § 13. “Two or three years ago.” The accusative is regularly used with ordinal numbers of days, months, and years (inclusive), to show when an event happened. οὑτοσὶ (never οὗτος) is often added.
Ἡραῖον τεῖχος. The site is uncertain, but it must have been close to the Chersonese.

τοὺς μέχρι πέντε καὶ τεττ. All citizens between the ages of twenty and sixty were liable to foreign service, but those over thirty were not very often called out. The exception in this case (as well as the emphatic αὐτούς) shows that the need was pressing.
τοῦ ἐνιαυτοῦ τούτου, i.e. the year ending in mid-July, 351—an interval of seven months since μαιμακτηριών.
ἑκατομβαιὼν, κ.τ.λ., sc. ἐπῇσαν.
μηνὸς μογ. μετὰ τὰ μυστ. Observe alliteration. Cf. supra, § 2.
τὰ μυστήρια. These took place during βοηδρομιών. This makes ten months since the time of ὅτ’ ἀπηγγέλθη.
κενάς = αὐτοὺς ἐμβαίνειν.
ἠγγέλθη . . . ασθενῶν. Cf. supra, § 4 (note).
τεθνεώς. For the strong perfect existing by the side of the weak τεθνηκώς, cf. ἑστώς and ἑστηκώς. In the indicative (as with ἵστημι) we find the strong form (τέθναμεν, τεθνᾶσι) only in the plural.
οὐκέτι. The ἔτι is emphatic. The Athenians, after so many postponements, thought that it was no good to send help now, whereas, says Demosthenes, this was (no credit to them) just the lucky moment.
ἀφεῖτε, “you countermanded.”
τὸν ἀπόστολον. For the special naval sense, cf. L. and S. στέλλω, II.
ἠνώχλει. One of the few verbs which take a double augment. The others are ἀντιβολεῖν, ἀντιδικεῖν, ἀμφισβητεῖν, ἀμφιγνοεῖν, διαιτᾶν, ἀνέχεσθαι, ἀνοίγειν, ἀμπέχεσθαι, ὁρᾶν (with διακονεῖν doubtful).
σωθείς. This is the emphatic word, with a reference to ἀσθενῶν ἢ τεθνεὼς above. Very freely: “Philip would never have been restored to health to be a thorn in our side now.”
οὐκ ἂν ἄλλως ἔχοι, literally “would not be in a different state,” i.e. “could not be altered” (however much we might try).

παντὶ σθένει. σθένος is an archaic and poetical word, and Dr. Sandys shows that it only survives (in prose) in the above phrase, “with might and main”: further, that κατὰ τὸ δυνατόν is not the language of Demosthenes, and that the five words are probably a quotation from a treaty ratified between Athens and Olynthus. The expression is found often in inscriptions which record treaties.
τινά. Cf. ii. § 1 (note).

ἐθάρρει τούτους, i.e. καὶ Φίλιππος ἐφοβεῖτο τούτους. θαρρεῖν, with acc., is a semi-poetical construction, an extension of that following commoner verbs of emotion, such as αἰσχύνομαι, καταπλήσσομαι, &c. The object is usually a thing, not a person: e.g. θάνατον θαρρεῖν (Plato, Phaedo, 88 B.).
ἡμεῖς, sc. πρὸς ἐκείνους.
ὥσπερ. L. and S. ὥσπερ, II.
ἐμπόδισμα . . . δυσχερές. Note the metaphor from hand and foot.

ἐφορμεῖν τοῖς ἑαυτοῦ καιροῖς. The last three words are commonly taken as “opportunities against him.” But ἐφορμεῖν can only be used of a fleet watching to strike: hence the dat. following, whether the verb is literal or metaphorical, must refer to the enemy. Translate, as Dr. Sandys, “his critical moments,” “his weak points.”
ἐκπολεμῶσαι. See note on i. § 7. Here the Φιλίππῳ is understood.
ὁπωσδήποτε. Disparaging; implying that the result was not due to Athens, but γέγον’ αὐτόματον (i. § 7, a passage which should be compared with this section).

περιστάσης ἄν. ἂν, with a participle, stands for a relative followed by ἂν and the finite mood demanded by the verb in the “if” clause. Curiously, ὑφείμεθα could be either aorist indic. or aorist opt., but the sense requires the latter. The full expression would be τῆς αἰσχύνης ἢ περισταίη ἄν.
καθυφείμεθα. The metaphor is from the slackening of sails, and is common in the simple verb.

ἐχόντων . . . ἀπειρ. Conditional participles, as we see from the μηδενὸς with ὄντος in the corresponding clause. Apart from this necessity, they would be better taken so than as causal, as they form the protasis to μικρὸν ὁρῶ. Thus, μικρὸν ἐσόμενον ὁρῶ, ἐὰν ἔχωσι . . . καὶ ἀπειρήκῃ.
ὡς ἔχουσι. Euphemistic for ἐχθρῶς.

ἀπειρηκότων δὲ κ.τ.λ., “and the resources of the Phocians are exhausted.” The primary idea of ἀπειπεῖν in post-Homeric times is “to say . . . not.” Hence it came to mean (1) “to forbid”; (2) “to renounce” (literally to say that you will have nothing to do with); (3) intrans., “to faint,” “fail” (literally to say that you cannot). The connection of (2) and (3) may be seen from the trans. and intrans. uses of “to give up” in English.
τὰ παρόντα. A vague way of referring to the Olynthians.

ἐπικλῖναι. Intransitive. “Not to ‘incline towards’ (L. and S.), but to ‘turn against,’ ‘press heavily on’” (Sandys). This is probably right, since the verb is used literally of the pressure of one substance against another.
ποιήσειν. The use of future instead of present serves to make the dilatoriness more marked.
ἔγγυθεν. Poetical word.
τὸ δ’ ὅπως. Cf. our phrase, “The why and the wherefore.”

νομοθέτας. A number of jurymen (we do not know how many) were yearly chosen to form a board to deal with changes in the laws. As such an appointment at the regular time could not be παράδοξον τοῖς πολλοῖς, we must assume either that Demosthenes proposes the establishment of an extra board, or that no election had taken place for the last year at least. The latter view is probable: it seems inconceivable that Demosthenes should not have said “appoint another board” of νομοθέται, if one was at this time sitting.
καθίσατε. A technical term. See L. and S., καθίζω, I. 4.
ἐν . . . νομοθέταις, “in their court.”
θῆσθε. For the difference between τιθέναι and τιθέσθαι νόμον see L. and S., τίθημι, A.V.

τῶν θεωρικῶν. The people had now come to regard as their right the dole which Pericles had first given them as a favour, and the surplus of yearly expenditure was now regularly paid into the Theoric Fund. It seems probable that Eubulus, at some time between 354 and 350, had passed laws (τοὺς εἰς τὸ παρὸν βλάπτοντας ὑμᾶς) forbidding the alienation of this fund. Hence, in i. § 19, Demosthenes only dares to hint at the nature of his proposal, and even here demands that the authors of the laws shall themselves incur the odium of repealing them. One Apollodorus (probably in 348) was fined by the law courts for actually passing such a proposal through the Senate and Assembly, and it was not till 339 that Demosthenes carried the day.

σαφῶς οὑτωσί, “to speak quite plainly.” οὕτως is idiomatically added for emphasis (probably with an accompanying gesture) to certain adverbs, especially σαφῶς and φανερῶς. Thus, ἄντικρυς οὑτωσί, “just outright;” οὕτω ῥᾳδίως, “quite easily.”
θεωρικά. Predicate.

τοὺς ἀτακτοῦντας, “malingerers;” literally “those who will not form
up along with the rest,” i.e. join the army. The rendering “disorderly” (L. and S.) makes no sense; Demosthenes is complaining that certain classes or individuals are exempted from service.
εἶτα. Causal. “And thus.”
τηνικαῦτα. Tum demum.
τὸν γράψοντα, “some one to propose.” The generalising use of the article with participle. So ὁ τυχών, “any chance-comer;” ὁ βουλόμενος, “any one who wishes.” Cf. ii. 1, τοὺς πολεμήσοντας (note).

ἀπολέσθαι. This refers no doubt to the loss of civil rights, not to the penalty of death. Any one who might propose the appropriation of the Theoric Fund would be indicted on a γραφὴ παρανόμων, or action for proposing illegal measures, as Apollodorus was afterwards: and this offence was punished, not by death, but by a fine. Until this was paid, the person found guilty would be ἄτιμος, and from a political point of view, ἀπολωλώς.
βουλήσεται, “shall be anxious to. . . .” Slightly ironical for “shall be prepared to.”
περιγίγνεσθαι. See L. and S., περιγίγνομαι, 3.
παθεῖν. For τοῦ παθεῖν, in apposition to τούτου.
τοὺς αὐτούς. Subject of λύειν.

τεθήκασιν. Inscriptions clearly show that forms like τέθεικα, ἐλελύκειν, εἰργαζόμην, &c., are far later than Attic. About the end of the second century B.C. εἰ began to supplant η in many words, mainly verbs, and as manuscripts were being largely multiplied at Alexandria at that period, many such barbaric forms have been perpetuated until our own time. Cf. note on ἕως, ii. 21.

χάριν. It is not strictly accurate to say that the “popularity” or “odium” affected the city for good or evil; it was affected by the proposals which made their originators popular or unpopular. The expressions are elliptical for χάριν τούτων ἃ . . . and ἀπέχθειαν τούτων δἰ ὧν.
ὑπάρχειν . . . γενέσθαι. Note the contrasting verbs and tenses. The popularity (won in the past) is spoken of as “continuing”; the odium (referring to the future) as being suddenly “incurred.”

ζημίαν. This predicate comes in awkwardly. The whole sentence should be so turned in translation as to give greater prominence to the persons spoken of: “that those who . . . should continue to enjoy . . . while the man who . . . should incur. . . .”
ἀξιοῦτε, literally “think fit,” i.e. “allow.” From the same literal meaning come the senses “require” or “demand” (supra, § 12, fin.), “ask” (iii. 3), “claim,” and “believe,” all with infinitive.

προθύμως, separated from ποιεῖν, that it may have an emphatic position towards the end of the sentence, while the still more emphatic position of ὑμᾶς makes it clear that the citizens themselves must act.
περὶ ὧν γραφείη, i.e. ταῦτα περὶ ὧν, “the objects for which they were passed.” The optative is used because the number of decrees is indefinite.
διαπράξασθαι, “to accomplish of themselves.” αὐτά would probably have been added but that the preceding αὐτάρκη is enough. The object is ταῦτα understood out of ὧν.
ὑβρίκει, sc. ἄν.
εἵνεκά γε ψηφισμάτων, “if resolutions could have done it.” This use of ἕνεκα for “as far as regards,” without any causal idea, is frequent both in prose and verse.
τῇ τάξει, “in order of time.”

τῇ δυνάμει, “essential importance” (Sandys). Not in the philosophic sense of “virtually,” “potentially” (as L. and S.). Stripped of its antithetical dress, the plain meaning is: The one important thing is action, not the debate which precedes it.
παρ’ ὑμῖν, s.c. εἰσί.
δυνάμενοι. We should expect οἱ δυν.
γνῶναι, “to decide on.” The verb never means to “know” except in perfect, ἔγνωκα (literally I have ascertained).
καὶ . . . δέ. An earlier writer would have written καὶ . . . γε or καὶ δὴ καί.
πρᾶξαι is emphatic, of action as opposed to speech and thought: ποιῆτε, neutral, of conduct, “if you do what you ought to do.”

οὐχ . . . πεισόμεθα. οὐχ goes with this verb as well as with προείληφε, not that it is “understood” in the second case, but because words like οὐ and εἰ can influence both parts of a μὲν . . . δὲ sentence, in the same way as a figure or letter in algebra influences everything contained in a bracket immediately following.
ταύτης, i.e. the land of the Olynthians, not Attica.
πάντων. Other passages in Demosthenes make it probable that this word is masculine.
πολεμήσαιεν . . . πολεμοῦνται. See note on i. § 7.
οὐκ ἐχθρός; A sudden and impressive change of subject.
ἔχων. More forcible than ἔχει, as being parallel with the two adjectives.

βάρβαρος. Although the races under Philip's rule at this time were mainly non-Hellenic, both Herodotus and Thucydides assert the Grecian descent of the reigning house. Both Alexander I. (some 130 years before) and Philip himself, in 356, had been allowed to compete, and had been victorious, in the Olympian games. But Macedon had held such slight intercourse with the Greek states that the bitter taunt is perhaps half justified; and the fact that Philip was a τύραννος (cf. i. § 5) would settle the question with the members of a free Greek state.
οὐχ ὅ τι ἂν . . . “Isn't he—anything you like to call him?” i.e. no name can be too bad.
μόνον οὐχί. Cf. i. § 2.

συγκατασκευάσαντες, “helping him to add them to his own pro
perty.” κατασκευή is a general word for the contents of an estate, including stock, furniture, outbuildings, &c.
τότε=τηνικαῦτα. Supra, § 11.
διὰ πάντας, κ.τ.λ. Emphatic: these are really οἱ αἴτιοι τῆς φυγῆς.
καὶ νῦν, κ.τ.λ. Three suppositions are put forward in the sentences οὐ λέγει . . . ἕτερος . . . and οὐχ ἡδέα . . . and after each comes the orator's reply.
ἀγαθῇ τύχῃ, “and may it bring good luck.” This was a formula used to preface decrees, and in ordinary life as a pious wish when any new step was being taken.

οὐκέτι ἀδικεῖ, “This is not the speaker's fault,” literally “not now,” as it was in the case of οὐβέλτιστα. Dr. Sandys sums up well the sense of καὶ νῦνἀδικεῖ: “Do not blame your advisers, but follow the best advice, however unpalatable it may prove.”
πλὴν εἰ . . . “unless he fails to put up a prayer when he ought.” Demosthenes ironically hints that the Athenians think more of formulas than of sound advice.
δέον εὐξ. παραλειπ. Beware the construction.
εἰς ταὐτό, like εἰς ἕν, “together.”
ἐν ὀλίγῳ. Probably here of space, not time: “in little compass.”
προτέθῃ. Put impersonally for πράγματα προτεθῇ. Note the careful antithesis of words between this sentence and the last: εὔξασθαι = ἑλέσθαι, ὅσα βούλεται = πράγματα, ῥᾴδιον = οὐκ εὔπορον.
φήμ’ ἔγωγε, εἴπερ ἔστιν, “I quite agree, if such a thing is possible.”
θαυμάζω εἰ. . . . More commonly this means, “I wonder that . . .”
εὐπορῆσαι, “to find means in.”

τῶν ἀπόντων, “what he has not” (Heslop), τῶν ἀπ. being opposed to τὰ παρόντα, “what he has,” merely to form a verbal antithesis. “What he has lost” is less probable: a state of poverty, not a change from riches, is implied in τῶν ἀπόντων.
εὐπορῆσαι, with gen., is slightly extended from its usual meaning, “to have good store of.”
μέγα ὑπάρχει. Either (1) “is a great support to,” or (2) “counts for much in,” as probably here.
ῥᾷστον . . . ἐστί, sc. τινί. Cf. supra, ii. § 23.

ὁρᾶτε . . . ὅπως, κ.τ.λ. All the three verbs that follow depend on ὅπως: “consider how the facts stand, and how you will be able . . .” οὕτως need not be translated. In the same way, for ταῦτα, though the direct object of ὁρᾶτε, we should say, “in regard to this.”
ἐνδέχεται. Generally impersonal.
σωφρόνων. σώφρων never means “wise.”
τῶν τοῦ πολέμου. Not with χρημάτων.
ἐπὶ μὲν . . . Φίλιππον δὲ. See note on ii. 24.
Κορινθίους καὶ Μεγαρέας. It has been thought that this refers either—
(1.) To the attack made on the two territories in 458, and on Megara by Pericles in 431.
(2.) To recent invasions of which we know nothing, though in Speech 13 (not written by Demosthenes) there is an incidental mention of an attack on the Megarid.
(3.) To neighbouring Greek states taken at random.
Probably (2) is correct. If Demosthenes had been thinking definitely of events 100 years old, he would have stated the facts more particularly.
Ἑλληνίδας. It is implied that Philip is βάρβαρος (supra, § 16).
ἐφοδ. τοῖς στρατ. Cf. i. 22, τροφῆς τοῖς ξένοις (note).
ἀκούω. In perfect sense: commoner than ἀκήκοα, where events which happened some time back are referred to.
οἱ παριόντες, sc. ἐπὶ τὸ βῆμα.
οὐ πάνυ. This may either be taken as “not at all,” its commonest meaning, or, more probably, as “not altogether,” ironical.
τῆς πολιτείας, “of statesmanship.”

τὸν Ἀριστείδην, κ.τ.λ. See Index of Proper Names. A special instance of public spirit on the part of Aristides may be found in the warning given to his enemy, Themistocles, before Salamis (Her. viii. 79), and on the part of Pericles in his brave defiance of the Athenians, when they clamoured to go out from the city against the Spartans who were ravaging their estates (Thuc. ii. 21-22). Nicias was nothing if not conscientious; the earlier Demosthenes we only know as a vigorous and capable general.
ἐκεῖνον=clarissimum illum.

οἱ διερωτῶντες, “who are always plying you with such questions as . . .” But note that “always” is expressed rather by the tense than by διά, which rarely expresses continuity of action, but often thoroughness or vigour, as may be seen from a study of the parallel words διέρεσθαι, διειπεῖν, διηγεῖσθαι, διϊσχυρίζεσθαι, &c.
πεφήνασι=exstiterunt.

προπέποται τῆς παραυτίκα χάριτος, “have been recklessly squandered for a momentary gratification.” The history and examples of προπίνω should be carefully studied in L. and S. It is unlikely that here there is any direct reference to “giving away in booncompanionship,” though in Fals. Leg. 296 (τ<>ν ε<>λενθερίαν προπεπωκότες Φιλ<>) Demosthenes uses the more literal meaning with effect, in view of orgies already mentioned. With the present passage cf. <*> (Hector rebuking the <*>
τῶν τε . . . καὶ τῶν, i.e. contrasting the one with the other. This disjunctive use of τε . . . καὶ is rare.
ἐφίλουν, “caressed.” Half-way between the common senses “to love” and “to kiss.”
αὐτούς. Note the change from relative to demonstrative, which always occurs where the first verb is followed by another which would require a different case.
πέντε καὶ τετταράκοντα ἔτη, i.e. from the formation of the Delian confederacy, 478-6, down to the outbreak of the Peloponnesian war in 431.

ἑκόντων. A very partial statement of the case. However willing the allies were to join the league originally, they constantly revolted throughout the period, and were one after another, with the exception of Chios and Lesbos, reduced to the condition of subjects.

πλείω ἢ μύρια τάλαντα. According to Thuc. ii. 13, the greatest amount of coined silver ever deposited in the Acropolis was 9700 talents, but he also mentions 500 talents of uncoined gold and silver as lying there at the beginning of the Peloponnesian war.
ἀνήγαγον, literally “carried up,” i.e. “deposited.”

ὑπήκουε. It is absurd to speak of the shifty Perdiccas II. as having been subject to the Athenians. He played fast and loose with Athens from the beginning of the war till his death, and, though entering into agreements with her more than once, did considerably more service to her enemies.
ταύτην, i.e. Macedonia. Cf. supra, § 16 (note).
ἔστησαν τροπαῖα, metaphorical. “Won triumphs.”
αὐτοί. Cf. i. § 9 (note).
μόνοι . . . κατέλιπον. Probably a reminiscence of Thuc. ii. 41 (from the funeral speech of Pericles), μόνη γὰρ (ἡ πόλις) τῶν νῦν ἀκοῆς κρείσσων ἐς πεῖραν ἔρχεται.
τῶν φθονούντων. Instead of τοῦ φθόνου. Concrete for abstract.
ἐπὶ . . . τῶν Ἑλλ., “in regard to.” A rare use, extended from such phrases as ἐπὶ πολλῶν (ii. 1). With Ἑλλ. understand πραγμάτων.

κάλλη . . . ἱερῶν. It is only in his most lofty passages that the orator would use such a poetical phrase, and it is for these higher flights that he reserves such sonorous language as that of ὥστε μηδενὶ τῶν ἐπιγιγνομένων ὑπερβολὴν λελεῖφθαι.
τῷ τῆς πολιτείας ἤθει, “the spirit of the constitution.” ἦθος (to be carefully distinguished from ἔθος) is that indefinable attribute of men and things which we call “character.”
ἦσαν μένοντες. See note on ii. § 26, ἔχον ἐστὶ φύσιν.
εἴ τις ἄρ’ οἶδεν, “if any of you happens to know,” ἄρα implying that there is no special reason why they should. This use of ἄρα is very common after ἢν (ἐὰν), “if it turns out that . . .”

ὁποία ποτέ=ὁποία τις, the addition of the enclitic making a slight difference, which cannot be kept up in English here. Thus ποῖός <>̓στι; means “what kind of man is he?” ποῖός τίς ἐστι; “what is his essential character?”
εἰς περιουσίαν, “with a view to amassing a fortune.”
ἐπράττετο αὐτοῖς. See i. § 28 (note).
τὸ κοινὸν αὔξειν. Cf. Hor. Od. ii. 15. 13:
“Privatus illis census erat brevis, Commune magnum.”
ἐκείνοις, i.e. τοῖς προγόνοις.
οἷς εἶπον. Attraction of relative, and of the antecedent into relative clause.
προστάταις. So during the Peloponnesian war the statesman most in favour with the people was called ὁ προστάτης τοῦ δήμου.
χρηστῶν, ironical. “Worthies” (Heslop).
οἷς—agrees with ἡμῖν above, but is left without construction, as the form of the sentence is changed at ἐπειλημμένοι.
ἂν ἔχων. Cf. supra, § 8 (note).
ὅσης. Cf. note on οἶς εἶπον above.
ἐρημίας. “‘A clear field,’ a metaphor from the public games, kept up in τῶν πρωτείων and βραβεύειν” (Sandys). In Phil. i. 49, τῶν κωλυσόντων is added.

ἐπειλημμένοι. The nom. participle is followed (in the same concessive sense) first by three genitive absolutes, and then by an accus. absolute, until the first construction is taken up in ἀπεστερήμεθα.
Λακεδ. . . . ἀπολωλ. At Leuctra in 371.
Θηβ. . . . ἀσχ. ὄντων. Since 355 the Thebans had been fully occupied with the Sacred War.
τὰ δίκαια, “the claims.”
χώρας οἰκείας. Amphipolis, Pydna, and Potidæa. Cf. i. § 12 (notes).
οὓς δ’ ἐν τῷ πολέμῳ συμμάχους. The war is that undertaken in 378 by the Athenians and Bœotians jointly against Sparta. In the same year Athens formed her second maritime league.
εἰρήνης οὔσης. The Social War waged by Athens against her revolted allies lasted 357-355, and during this period Athens was at peace with the other Grecian states.
ἠσκήκαμεν, “trained.” For the metaphor see § 27, note on ἐρημίας.
ἤ. Cf. ii. § 8 (note).
ἀλλ’ ὦ τᾶν. See i. § 26 (note).
λήρους, “absurd trifles.” Demosthenes charges Eubulus and the peace party with distracting the minds of the people from external dangers by means of a few paltry improvements in the city.
τῶν πολιτευομένων, masc. middle.
ἀγαπητόν. For the verb ἀγαπᾶν see ii. 19 (note).
τῶν ἄλλων ἑκάστῳ, i.e. τοῖς πολιτευομένοις.

ἐκνενευρισμένοι, “have had your sinews ripped out.” The metaphor is strange to English, and we can scarcely do justice to the idea of moral deterioration implied in the loss of “fibre.” It is highly improbable that “sinews of war” are meant, though this view has met with some support owing to the next words (περιῃρ. χρημ.).
ἐν ὑπηρ. . . . γεγένησθε, “have been reduced to the position of mere servants and appendages.” Cf. ii. 18, ἐν οὐδενὸς μέρει. ii. 14, ἐν προσθήκῃ.

Βοηδρόμια πέμψωσιν, “celebrate the procession of the Boedromia.” This festival was held on the 6th day of the month Βοηδρομιών (about September 26), in honour of Apollo Βοηδρόμιος (Helper in battle), and Artemis the Huntress. It commemorated a mythical Athenian victory, but whether that gained by Theseus over the Amazons or by Erectheus over Eumolpus is uncertain. There is a curious reading Βοΐδια given for Βοηδρόμια by ancient citers of Demosthenes: it is probably due to a copyist who did not understand the above use of πέμπειν.
τὸ πάντων ἀνδρειότατον, “bravest thing of all,” in apposition to the next clause. Demosthenes here puts ironically what he had said above seriously in ἐκνενευρισμένοι.
αὐτῶν does not, of course, agree with τῶν ὑμετέρων. Cf. ii. 24.
οἱ δέ, demonstrative.
καθείρξαντες. The people are “cooped up” in the city like animals in a cage, to be tamed.
ἐπάγουσιν ἐπὶ ταῦτα, “coax you on to these enjoyments.” The same metaphor is kept up to the end of the sentence.
νεανικόν. Sometimes used in a bad sense, derived from the folly (not, as here, from the high spirit) of youth.

ὁποῖ̓ ἄττα γὰρ ἂν. The indefinite ἂν, with subjunctive, can only be separated from its relative or conjunction by little words like μέν, γάρ, &c. ὁποῖ̓ ἄττα are regarded as one word, as in i. § 28, ὁποῖ̓ ἄττ’ ἂν . . . περιστῇ.
ταῦτα. Accusative after εἰπόντι, which here means “tell of,” not “say.”
τῶν πεποιηκότων=ἢ τοῖς πεποιηκόσιν.
ἀλλὰ νῦν γ’ ἔτι, “even now.” ἀλλὰ νῦν and ἀλλὰ σὺν χρόνῳ are common in tragedy.
ἀφορμαῖς, predicate.
τἄξω τῶν ἀγαθῶν=τἄξω ἀγαθά.
τέλειον, “consummate.”
λημμάτων, “petty gains”; generally with an idea of dishonesty.

τοῖς ἀσθενοῦσι . . . σιτίοις διδομένοις. The two datives and the position of the article make this sentence a very clumsy one. If the text is sound, we can only take the words in the following order: ἃ ἔοικε τοῖς σιτίοις διδομένοις ἀσθενοῦσι, for though ἀσθενοῦσι seems sorely to need an article, σιτίοις must have one. The tone of voice would easily prevent any ambiguity in the actual delivery. Of course it is easy to cut out ἀσθενοῦσι, but this is a policy of despair.

παρὰ τῶν ἰατρῶν . . . διδομένοις. Not “given by doctors:” this would introduce a use of παρά, which, though found in Herodotus and Plato, would be impossible in the more chastened prose of the orators. Taken in conjunction with Plat. Rep. 406 D, φάρμακον πιεῖν παρὰ τοῦ ἰατροῦ (“to drink doctor's stuff”), we may say that the phrase means “in medical practice,” literally “from the quarter of doctors.”
καὶ . . . καί, “as . . . so.”
ἃ νέμεσθε, “which are your portion,” possibly with a contemptuous reference to cattle feeding, this being the commonest sense of the middle.
διαρκῆ, “adequate.” Not “lasting” (L. and S.)
ἀπογνόντας, sc. αὐτά. “To give them up and . . .”
ἔστι . . . ἐπαυξάνοντα. Cf. supra, § 25, and ii. § 26 (note).
μισθοφοράν, i.e. do you propose to apply the Theoric Fund to the payment of citizen soldiers?
καὶ . . . ἁπάντων. An inadvertent hexameter.
σύνταξιν, literally “arrangement of,” i.e. “system for” all. ἁπάντων, masc.
τοῦθ’ ὑπάρχοι, literally “might be that” which, i.e. “might exercise those functions” which. The ending is rather unexpectedly put for something like τοῦτο πράξειε.

ὑπάρχοι here furnishes one of the few instances of an optative following a primary verb (λέγω understood from λέγεις). This construction may be used where the principal verb refers to action in the past which is still continued in the present. Thus here the idea is, “this measure I determined upon and now propose.” Cf. Aristoph. Frogs, 23, τοῦτον δ’ ὀχῶ | ἵνα μὴ ταλαιπωροῖτο, “I (took him up and) am carrying him, that he might not . . .”
ἔξεστιν . . . Demosthenes shows how the scheme will work in three respects: (1) in peace, (2) in war, (3) as to those past the age for military service.
βελτίων, sc. ἔσται ἢ νῦν. The citizens will be all the better for the new scheme, because they will receive payment for serving the state at home in various ways, and be enabled to live respectably.
ὑπάρχων, sc. βελτίων ἔσται ἢ νῦν.
ἀπό, “receiving pay from.”
ἐστὶ δίκαιον, sc. στρατιώτην ὑπάρχειν.
ἔξω τῆς ἡλικίας. At the age of sixty an Athenian was exempted from further service.
ἀτάκτως, “irregularly.”
οὐκ ὠφελεῖ, sc. τὴν πόλιν.
ἐν ἴσῃ τάξει, “on an equal system.”

οὔτ’ ἀφελὼν οὔτε προσθεὶς πλὴν μικρῶν. I have little hesitation in keeping μικρῶν, the best-supported reading, and in preferring the explanation given by Dr. Sandys, that the words refer to the expenditure of public money. “Without adding or subtracting anything to speak of in expense.” Others, reading πλὴν μικρόν, take it with the words that follow, “except that in a small degree
I have . . .”; but Demosthenes is contending that he has in no small degree made order out of chaos.
ἔχοι, sc. ποιεῖν, “is able to do.”
ἀπορεῖν, “to be poor, helpless creatures.”
τοῦ δεῖνος. See ii. § 31 (note).
τῆς τάξεως . . . τῆς ἀρετῆς, “that glorious post.” τῆς ἀρετῆς is attracted into the relative clause for the sake both of euphony and emphasis.
σχεδόν modestly qualifies εἴρηκα, “I think I have said.”
ἕλοισθε . . . συνοίσειν. Cf. i. § 28 (note on χρηστὰ δ’ εἴη).
